content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Eric Johnson: I was born in Munich, Germany, but I moved to the United States when I was about five years old. My family settled in Columbia, South Carolina, and I've lived here ever since. Growing up, my parents worked hard to make ends meet. They both had only a high school education, so they took on a lot of manual labor jobs. My mom worked part-time at a local store, and my dad did odd jobs around town. It wasn't easy, but we always had enough to get by. I grew up in a small house on Elm Street, and I remember my childhood being pretty simple—just the basics, no luxuries. I didn't have a lot of money, but I had a strong sense of family and community. I was always the kind of kid who liked to read and learn, even though I didn't have a lot of resources. I graduated high school a few years ago, and now I'm working toward my GED while I'm in community college. I speak a little German from my parents, but I've mostly grown up speaking English. I'm not sure what the future holds yet, but I'm trying to stay focused on my education and see where that takes me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Eric Johnson: There was one moment that really shaped my path, and it happened when I was about sixteen. I had just finished my junior year of high school, and I was starting to realize that I wasn't going to be able to afford college the way I had always dreamed. My parents were doing their best, but with both of them working low-paying jobs, there wasn't much left over for things like tuition or books. I remember sitting at the kitchen table one night, looking at my report card and thinking about what my future would look like if I didn't go to college. I felt stuck, like I was going to be trapped in the same cycle my parents were in. But then, my mom sat down next to me and said something that stuck with me. She told me, 'You don't have to be rich to be successful, but you do have to be smart about your choices.' That conversation really opened my eyes. I realized that I didn't have to wait for someone else to give me a chance—I could take control of my own future. I started working part-time at a local bookstore to save up for community college, and I also began volunteering at a community center where I helped tutor kids who were struggling in school. That experience gave me a new perspective on education and the power it can have. It also helped me decide that I wanted to go back to school and earn my GED so I could have more options. That moment was a crossroads for me, and I chose to take the path that would give me the best chance to build a better life—not just for myself, but for my family too.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Eric Johnson: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made all at once. It felt more like a series of small decisions that added up over time. At first, I was just trying to survive—getting through high school, working extra hours, helping out at the community center. But as I kept pushing forward, I started to see that each step I took, whether it was studying late at night or saving every dollar I could, was part of a bigger plan. I didn't have a clear roadmap, but I knew I didn't want to end up in the same place my parents were. So I made the choice to take responsibility for my future, even if it meant sacrificing some things in the present. I think that's what my mom meant when she said I had to be smart about my choices. It wasn't just about making the right decision—it was about staying committed to it, no matter how hard it got.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Eric Johnson: Absolutely, and I think that's something I've come to appreciate more as I've gotten older. When I was sixteen and feeling stuck, I didn't know where to turn. But there were a few people who really helped me out—my high school counselor, Mrs. Thompson, was one of them. She saw the stress I was under and actually sat down with me to talk about my options. She didn't just tell me what I could do; she helped me realize that I had options. She connected me with a local scholarship program for students who were working while in school, and that gave me the chance to get some financial support for community college. Then there was the community center where I volunteered. The director there, Mr. Hayes, saw potential in me and encouraged me to keep pushing forward, even when I felt like I wasn't making progress. He even let me use the center's library for study time after hours. I think people like them made a huge difference in my life, but I also know that I couldn't have done it without my own determination. It was a team effort, but I had to be ready to take the help when it came.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Eric Johnson: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children. My family is my parents and my younger sister, Lisa. She's twelve and still in middle school, and she's actually the one who keeps me grounded. Even though we didn't have a lot growing up, she always believed in me more than I believed in myself sometimes. My parents are still living in the same house on Elm Street, and while things are better now, they're still working hard to make ends meet. My dad recently started doing some freelance handyman work, and my mom got a full-time position at the grocery store, which has helped a bit. I see them every day, and I know that whatever I accomplish, it's because of their sacrifices. I want to make sure I can provide for them in the future, even if it takes longer than I'd like. Right now, I'm focused on finishing my GED and getting into a better program at the community college. I think once I have that under my belt, I'll be able to start looking into more opportunities—maybe even something in business or management. I just hope I can make them proud.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how far I've come and how much my family, my choices, and the support I received along the way have shaped who I am today. Talking about my childhood reminded me of the struggles my parents faced and how their resilience taught me the value of hard work. The moment I described when I was sixteen was a turning point, and realizing it was a series of small, conscious decisions rather than one big moment helped me understand my own growth better. I also felt grateful when I thought about the people who helped me—Mrs. Thompson, Mr. Hayes, and even my mom and sister—because it reminded me that I didn't have to do this alone. And now, thinking about my family and my future, I feel a deep sense of responsibility to keep pushing forward, not just for myself, but for them. It's all connected, and I'm finally starting to see the path ahead more clearly.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Eric Johnson: Actually, there's my uncle Markus, who lives in Berlin. He's the one who kept in touch with us after I moved to the U.S. He used to visit us every few years when he came over for business, and he always brought little gifts from Germany—like traditional toys or books. He was the one who taught me how to speak a little German, even though I don't use it much anymore. We haven't talked in a while, but I know he's still proud of me. He used to say that I had a quiet strength, and I think that's something I've come to realize about myself over time. Even though I don't see him often, I feel like he's always been a part of my journey in some way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Eric Johnson: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me. One of them is Jamal, who I met in high school. We were in the same classes and both struggled with figuring out what we wanted to do after school. He ended up joining the military, and I admire his courage and discipline. Even though our paths have taken us in different directions, we still keep in touch. Then there's Sarah, who works at the community center where I volunteered. She became like a second sister to me—always encouraging me, pushing me to keep going when I felt like giving up. She even helped me with some of my GED study materials. I think the people who have stayed in my life are the ones who saw something in me before I saw it in myself. They reminded me that I was worth fighting for, even when I didn't feel like it. I don't have a lot, but I'm grateful for the people who have been there for me along the way.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Eric Johnson: I live in a pretty tight-knit neighborhood on Elm Street, just like I did when I was a kid. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, and there's a real sense of community. Some of the houses are older, with small yards and simple designs, but there's a charm to it that you don't always find in bigger cities. The street is quiet most of the time, except for the usual sounds of kids playing or the occasional car passing by. There's a local park a few blocks away where I used to hang out with my sister, and it's still a place where people gather for picnics or just to sit and chat. I like that about Columbia—it feels like a place where people take time to care for each other, even if things aren't perfect. I've seen a lot of changes in the neighborhood over the years, but I think the heart of it has stayed the same. It's not the most exciting place in the world, but it's home, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Eric Johnson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not like the bigger cities I've heard about where things can get chaotic, but there's always a sense of watchfulness. If you're out on Elm Street after dark, you know someone's probably looking out for you. I've never had any real issues, and I think that's because people here tend to take care of each other. My neighbors are mostly older folks who've lived here for decades, and they know everyone's business in a way that's not intrusive—it's more like a protective instinct. I remember when I was younger, I used to worry about walking home from the store at night, but now I don't think twice about it. I guess that's the kind of place this is. It's not perfect, but it's safe, and that matters a lot when you don't have much else.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Eric Johnson: Living here has had its challenges, but it's also given me a strong foundation. The downside is that opportunities aren't always easy to come by. There aren't a lot of high-paying jobs around here, and sometimes it feels like the same struggles my parents faced are just repeating themselves. But the upside is that this place has taught me resilience. I've seen neighbors help each other through tough times, whether it's fixing a broken fence or just offering a listening ear. I think that kind of support system is something I'll carry with me wherever I go. It's not glamorous, but it's real. I've also learned to appreciate the little things—like the way the sun hits the old oak tree in our front yard or how the community comes together for local events. I know I don't have a lot, but I'm proud of where I'm from, and I think that pride has helped me keep going when things got tough.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply connected I am to the people and place that shaped me. Talking about my parents and sister made me realize how much their sacrifices and support have influenced my journey. It also made me think about how important it is to give back, not just to them, but to the community that has always been there for me. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a sense of pride in the simplicity and safety of Elm Street, even though it's not the most exciting place. It's where I grew up, and it's where I learned the value of resilience and community. I think the interview helped me see that my roots are strong, and even though I'm still figuring out my future, I know I have a solid foundation to build on.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Eric Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also pretty flexible depending on what I need to get done. I usually wake up around 6:30 or 7 in the morning, make a quick breakfast, and then head to community college. Classes are usually from 8 to 11, and then I have some time to study or work on my GED prep. After that, I work part-time at the bookstore from 1 to 4, which helps me stay focused and also gives me a little extra income. In the evenings, I try to spend time with my sister or help my parents out with whatever they need—sometimes it's just cooking dinner, other times it's fixing something around the house. On weekends, I like to take it easy, but I also try to keep up with my studies. I'll often go to the library or study at the community center after hours, especially if I'm working on an assignment or preparing for a test. I also make sure to check in with my friends or family, just to keep things grounded. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I've learned to prioritize what matters most. I know that consistency is key, and even though I don't have a lot, I'm trying to make the most of every day.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Eric Johnson: I work part-time at a local bookstore, which is actually owned by an older couple named Mr. and Mrs. Carter. They're both retired teachers, and they've been nothing but kind to me. I work there three days a week, usually from 1 to 4 in the afternoon. It's a quiet job, but I enjoy it because I get to read a lot of different books, and I've even started recommending some to customers. It's a good way to pass the time and also earn a little extra money. I think the best part about working there is that the Carters trust me to handle things on my own, which makes me feel responsible. I've learned a lot from them—not just about books, but about patience and how to treat people with respect. It's a simple job, but it helps me stay grounded and reminds me that even small roles can be meaningful if you put your heart into them.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Eric Johnson: Outside of work and school, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay focused. Every evening after I get home, I try to spend at least an hour reading or studying, even if it's just a few pages of my GED materials. I find that having a small, consistent habit like that helps me feel like I'm making progress, even when things are slow. I also try to keep a journal where I write down my thoughts, goals, and even just random ideas that come to me. It's not something I used to do, but I started doing it after talking to Sarah at the community center. She said it helped her stay on track when she was going through school, and I think it's been helpful for me too. On top of that, I've started going for short walks around the neighborhood in the evenings, especially when I'm feeling stressed or overwhelmed. It's a way to clear my head and remind myself that even though life can feel heavy at times, there's still beauty in the little things around me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Eric Johnson: One of the biggest changes to my routine has been starting to take online courses through the community college, which has given me more flexibility with my schedule. I used to have to stick strictly to the in-person classes, but now I can fit in some of my GED prep work during the evenings or on days when I'm not working. It's been a bit of a learning curve, especially with the technology, but I've gotten the hang of it. I also started helping my dad with some of his freelance work—like organizing his tools or helping him with small repair jobs around the neighborhood. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of contributing, and it's also been a good way to learn more about how things work. I think these changes have helped me feel more in control of my time, and I'm starting to see that even small shifts can make a big difference in how I approach my goals.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Eric Johnson: Actually, I don't have children yet, so I haven't had the experience of managing a child's daily routine. But I can tell you that my sister, Lisa, is the one who keeps me grounded, and I often think about what it would be like to have a child of my own. I imagine that it would be a mix of the same structure I have now—early mornings, school, responsibilities—but with even more care and attention. I know that being a parent would mean making sacrifices, just like my parents did for me, and I want to make sure I'm ready for that kind of commitment. For now, I'm focused on my own journey, but I think about the future a lot, especially when I see how hard my parents have worked to give me a chance. I hope that one day, I can be the kind of role model for my own family that they were for me.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and place that shaped me. Talking about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how much their sacrifices and support have influenced my journey. It also made me think about how important it is to give back, not just to them, but to the community that has always been there for me. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a sense of pride in the simplicity and safety of Elm Street, even though it's not the most exciting place. It's where I grew up, and it's where I learned the value of resilience and community. I think the interview helped me see that my roots are strong, and even though I'm still figuring out my future, I know I have a solid foundation to build on.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Eric Johnson: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major issues, but I do struggle with stress from time to time, especially with balancing school, work, and helping out at home. I used to get headaches a lot when I was younger, but I think that's mostly gone now. I try to stay active by walking around the neighborhood or doing some light lifting when I help my dad with his work. I also make sure to eat reasonably well—nothing fancy, but I try to keep it balanced. My mom always reminds me to take care of myself, and I think that's something I've been getting better at. I don't go to the doctor often, but I know when something's off, and I make sure to take care of it. Overall, I feel healthy enough to keep pushing forward, and I think that's one of the reasons I'm able to keep going with my goals.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Eric Johnson: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is knowing that I have a routine, even if it's simple. I don't have a lot of time or money for fancy gym memberships or expensive supplements, but I do what I can with what I have. Walking around the neighborhood, helping my dad with small jobs, and even just stretching while I'm studying—it all adds up. The hard part is when stress gets the best of me, especially when I'm juggling school, work, and helping out at home. I used to ignore the signs, like when I'd feel tired or get a headache, but I've learned that pushing through without taking care of myself isn't worth it. Now, I try to listen to my body more. If I feel overwhelmed, I'll take a break, even if it's just for ten minutes, and breathe deeply. I think the biggest challenge is staying consistent, but I'm learning that small habits—like eating a balanced meal or getting enough sleep—can make a big difference in how I feel overall.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Eric Johnson: In the past two years, I haven't had any major health issues, but there was a time when I was really struggling with anxiety. It started around the time I was trying to balance my GED studies with my part-time job and helping out at home. I was constantly feeling overwhelmed, and it got to the point where I couldn't sleep well at night. I remember one evening, I was sitting at the kitchen table, trying to study, and I just felt like everything was too much. I didn't know how to ask for help, so I tried to push through it on my own. But eventually, I talked to Sarah at the community center, and she encouraged me to see a counselor through the local health clinic. That was a big step for me—admitting that I needed support. The counselor helped me understand what I was going through and gave me some strategies to manage my stress. I started practicing deep breathing exercises and setting small, achievable goals for myself. It wasn't easy, but it made a difference. I think that experience taught me that taking care of my mental health is just as important as taking care of my physical health. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful that I didn't ignore it this time.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Eric Johnson: Honestly, I think my anxiety did affect me in some ways, especially when I was trying to keep up with everything. There were days when I felt so overwhelmed that I couldn't focus on my studies or even remember simple tasks. I remember one time, I was working at the bookstore and I just froze—my mind went blank, and I couldn't remember where the books were or how to help a customer. It was embarrassing, but it also made me realize how much my stress was taking a toll. I didn't want to let it define me, though. I started setting smaller goals for myself, like just getting through one chapter of my GED book or taking a short walk after work to clear my head. It wasn't much, but it helped me feel more in control. I think the biggest thing I learned is that I can't do everything at once. I have to take it one step at a time, and that's something I'm still working on. But I'm grateful that I didn't let it stop me from moving forward.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Eric Johnson: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just barely keeping my head above water. I've been working harder than ever to finish my GED and keep up with my community college classes, and it's been exhausting, but also rewarding. I think the biggest thing that's changed for me is that I've started to believe in myself more. I used to feel like I was just going through the motions, trying to survive instead of thriving. But now, I see the small victories—like passing a test or finishing a chapter of my GED book without getting overwhelmed. I've also started to feel more connected to my community again. I've been helping out more at the community center, and it's reminded me of why I started this journey in the first place. I want to be someone who can make a difference, not just for myself, but for others. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to stay focused on the long game. I know I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm getting there, one step at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily life has evolved over the past few months, and how important it is to take care of both my mind and body. Talking about my routine changes reminded me that even small adjustments—like taking online classes or helping my dad with his work—can have a big impact on how I feel about my future. It also made me realize how much I've grown in learning to manage stress and prioritize my health, especially after struggling with anxiety. I used to think I had to push through everything on my own, but now I understand that asking for help and taking time to breathe is just as important as working hard. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more in control than I ever have before, and that gives me hope for what's ahead.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Eric Johnson: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially in the past year. It's not something I used to talk about, but I've come to realize that it's a real part of my life, and it's okay to acknowledge it. There were times when I felt like I was carrying everything on my own, and that weight made it hard to breathe. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could outlast the stress. But I've learned that ignoring it doesn't make it go away. I've started seeing a counselor, and it's been a big help. She's taught me how to recognize the signs of anxiety before it takes over and how to manage it with things like deep breathing, meditation, and setting realistic goals for myself. I still have bad days, but I'm not as afraid of them anymore. I know now that it's not a weakness to ask for help, and I'm trying to be kinder to myself when I feel overwhelmed. I think the hardest part is still learning how to balance everything without burning out, but I'm getting better at it. I want to be someone who can support others, just like the people who supported me, and I think taking care of my mental health is the first step in making that happen.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Eric Johnson: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and quiet moments of hope. My parents have been working harder than ever to keep things stable, especially with my dad taking on more freelance work. My mom's full-time job at the grocery store has helped, but it's still a tight budget. They've always been the kind of people who put others first, so I know they're worried about me, especially with all the stress I've been going through with school and my mental health. My sister, Lisa, has been my rock—she's the one who reminds me to take a break when I'm overwhelmed and who still believes in me even when I don't believe in myself. I think they've all been holding their breath, hoping that I'll find my way, and I want them to know that I'm doing everything I can. It's not just about me anymore; it's about showing them that their sacrifices weren't in vain and that I can build something better for us all.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Eric Johnson: I wouldn't say religion or spirituality plays a big role in my life the way it does for some people. Growing up, my family didn't really practice any particular faith, and I never really felt the need to fill that space with something formal. I think I've always been more of a person who looks for meaning in the everyday—like the way my mom works so hard to provide for us, or how my neighbors look out for each other on Elm Street. I don't have a lot of answers about life's bigger questions, but I do believe in the power of people helping one another, and that feels like something worth holding onto. I guess if I had to describe it, I'd say I'm more of a spiritual person in the sense that I believe in the strength of the human spirit, even when things are hard. It's not about praying to a higher power, but more about finding hope in the little things and trusting that, even when life feels overwhelming, there's still a way forward.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Eric Johnson: To be honest, I don't use social media much. I know a lot of people my age are on Facebook or Instagram, but I've never really felt the need to be connected that way. I think it's more because I grew up in a pretty quiet neighborhood where everyone knows each other, so I don't feel like I'm missing out on anything. I do use my phone to stay in touch with my friends and family, especially Jamal and Sarah, but I mostly send text messages or call them directly. I've seen how social media can be a double-edged sword—sometimes it's good for staying connected, but other times it can feel like a lot of noise without any real meaning. I guess I just prefer keeping things simple. I don't want to waste time scrolling through posts when I could be studying or helping out at home. Plus, with everything going on in my life, I think I need to be more intentional about how I spend my time.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Eric Johnson: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support, even during tough times. I know some people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but for me, it's always felt more like a distraction than a help. I've had moments where I thought about posting something, like when I was dealing with my anxiety or feeling overwhelmed with everything going on, but I never followed through. I guess I just didn't want to expose my struggles to people I didn't know, or maybe I didn't want to feel like I was being judged. Instead, I've always turned to the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, or even my neighbors. They've been the ones who've offered me real support, not just likes or comments. I think that's why I don't use social media much—it's not that I don't want to connect, but I prefer the kind of connection that feels genuine and meaningful, not just virtual.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how much my mental health has shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my struggles with anxiety reminded me of how much I used to carry everything on my own, thinking that pushing through was the only way to survive. But now I understand that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a sign of strength. I've learned that taking small steps, like breathing deeply or setting achievable goals, can make a real difference in how I feel. It also made me realize how much my family and friends have supported me, even when I didn't ask for it. I'm still learning how to balance everything without burning out, but I'm grateful that I'm not alone in this. I want to be someone who can support others the way I've been supported, and I think taking care of my mental health is the first step in making that happen.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Eric Johnson: In the past few months, I've actually felt a little less overwhelmed, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've started to find a better balance between my responsibilities and my mental health. I've been more consistent with my breathing exercises and I've even started journaling more regularly, which helps me process my thoughts before they spiral. I've also been trying to set smaller, more manageable goals for myself, like focusing on one task at a time instead of trying to do everything at once. It's not perfect, and there are still days when I feel like I'm barely holding on, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself when that happens. I've also started talking more openly with my family about how I'm feeling, which has made a big difference. My mom used to worry about me, but now she knows I'm trying my best, and that gives me a sense of peace. I think the biggest change is that I'm no longer afraid to ask for help when I need it, and that has made all the difference in how I handle stress and worry now.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Eric Johnson: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and utilities. We live in a small two-bedroom apartment on Elm Street, and the rent is about $650 a month. That's a big chunk of our budget, especially since both my parents are still working low-paying jobs. Groceries are another major expense—my mom works at the grocery store, but we still have to buy food for the whole family, and it adds up. We try to buy in bulk and stick to basics to save money. Utilities are also a concern, especially during the hotter months when the air conditioner runs nonstop. We've been trying to cut back on unnecessary things, like eating out or buying new clothes, but it's not always easy. My part-time job at the bookstore helps a little, and I've been saving some of my earnings for my GED and college expenses. It's a tight budget, but we're managing, and I know that every dollar we save brings us one step closer to a better future.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Eric Johnson: Our household spent around $1,800 last month, and that's pretty much in line with what we usually spend. Rent is the biggest chunk, as I mentioned, and then groceries come next. We try to keep our expenses as tight as possible, especially since my parents don't make a lot. I also contribute what I can from my job at the bookstore, which helps a little with the bills. We don't have a lot of discretionary spending—no cable, no fancy dinners out, just the essentials. I think the hardest part is knowing that even with all our sacrifices, we're still just barely getting by. But I also know that every dollar we save is one step closer to my being able to finish my GED and get into a better program. It's not easy, but I'm trying to stay focused on the long game.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Eric Johnson: We rent our home, actually. It's a small two-bedroom apartment on Elm Street, just like the house I grew up in. Renting has always been the way to go for us because buying a house just isn't realistic with our income. My parents have been working hard to keep up with the payments, and I've been helping out as much as I can with the bills from my part-time job. It's not ideal, but it's what works for us right now. I remember when I was younger, I used to think that owning a home was the mark of success, but now I realize that stability is more important than status. As long as we have a roof over our heads and can keep the lights on, I think we're doing okay. I just hope that one day, I can help my parents move into something more comfortable, but for now, renting is what keeps us afloat.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Eric Johnson: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons. In the summer, our electricity bill goes up because we use the air conditioner a lot, and that's something we haven't been able to afford much of. We've had to be really careful about turning it off when we're not home or using fans instead. In the winter, heating is a concern too, but we've been lucky that it's not as cold here in Columbia as it is in other parts of the country. Holidays are another thing—around Christmas, we try to keep it simple, but we still have to buy gifts for each other, and that adds a little extra to the budget. I remember last year, my sister wanted a new backpack for school, and even though it wasn't expensive, it felt like a big splurge at the time. Then there's the cost of my GED and college materials, which I've been paying for out of my own earnings. It's not much, but it adds up when you're trying to balance everything. I think the biggest fluctuation has been with my parents' income—when my dad gets more freelance work, it helps, but when he's slower, we have to tighten the belt even more. It's been a learning experience, and I've started keeping track of our expenses more carefully, just so I know where the money is going. It's not always easy, but I think it's helping us stay afloat.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my mental health and the support I've received from my family and friends have shaped my journey. Talking about my struggles with anxiety reminded me of how much I used to carry everything on my own, thinking that pushing through was the only way to survive. But now I understand that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a sign of strength. I've learned that taking small steps, like breathing deeply or setting achievable goals, can make a real difference in how I feel. It also made me realize how much my family and friends have supported me, even when I didn't ask for it. I'm still learning how to balance everything without burning out, but I'm grateful that I'm not alone in this. I want to be someone who can support others the way I've been supported, and I think taking care of my mental health is the first step in making that happen.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Eric Johnson: I try to save in small ways whenever I can, even if it's just a few dollars here and there. I have a little jar on my shelf at home where I put any extra money I earn from my job at the bookstore or from doing odd jobs around the neighborhood. It might not seem like much, but it's something. I also try to set aside a portion of my paycheck every week, even if it's just $10 or $20. I know that saving is something I need to get better at, especially if I want to have a financial cushion for the future. Right now, my main goal is to save enough to cover my GED fees and maybe even start putting something aside for my community college classes. I don't have a savings account yet because I don't have a lot of money to open one, but I'm thinking about opening one soon. I want to be responsible with my money, not just for myself, but for my family too. It's a small step, but I think it's one that matters.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Eric Johnson: In the last year, I've been saving mostly for the future—specifically for my education and the things that will help me build a better life. I know it might sound small, but every dollar I save feels like a step toward something bigger. Right now, my main goal is to save enough to cover my GED fees and maybe even start putting something aside for my community college classes. I don't have a lot, but I want to be responsible with what I have. I think saving for the future, even in small ways, gives me a sense of control and hope. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared for what's ahead, and I know that's something my parents would be proud of.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Eric Johnson: My occupation right now is a part-time worker at the local bookstore, but I also spend a lot of time studying for my GED and attending community college classes. The work at the bookstore is pretty straightforward—organizing shelves, helping customers find books, and occasionally managing the cash register. It's not the most exciting job, but it gives me a sense of responsibility and helps me stay grounded. The most important part of my job is interacting with people. I've learned that even small conversations with customers can be meaningful, and it's amazing how much you can learn from listening to others. I also enjoy recommending books to people, especially when they're looking for something new. It's a way to connect with others and share a little bit of what I love about reading. Beyond that, my main duties are really about balancing my time between work, school, and helping out at home. It's not always easy, but I try to stay focused on what matters most—my education and my future.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Eric Johnson: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week at the bookstore, depending on the season and how busy things get. Some weeks, especially during the school year, I might work a little less because I have more classes or study time to focus on. Other times, like during holidays or when I need to save up for something specific, I'll pick up a few extra shifts. It's not a lot, but it helps me stay on my feet and also gives me a little more freedom to manage my time between school, work, and helping out at home. I think the key is finding that balance—working enough to earn some money but not so much that I don't have time to take care of myself or my responsibilities. It's a tightrope walk, but I'm learning to walk it one step at a time.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Eric Johnson: Actually, I haven't had more than one job at a time, but I've done a few different kinds of work over the years. When I was younger, I used to help my dad with small repair jobs around the neighborhood—like fixing fences or painting houses. It wasn't steady work, but it gave me a sense of responsibility and also helped me learn a few handy skills. Then, when I was in high school, I worked at a local grocery store, which was my first real job. It was tough at first, especially because I was still trying to keep up with school, but it taught me a lot about time management and working with people. Now, I'm at the bookstore, and while it's a different kind of work, it's still about serving others and staying focused. I think the key for me has always been to find work that fits into my life rather than letting work take over my life. I don't have the luxury of having multiple jobs right now, but I'm grateful for the one I have because it gives me the flexibility I need to keep going with my education and support my family.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding my own stress and emotional needs. Talking about my recent changes in stress levels reminded me that I'm not as overwhelmed as I used to be, and that's because I've started taking better care of myself—whether it's through breathing exercises, journaling, or setting smaller goals. It also made me realize how important it is to be open with my family about how I'm feeling, because their support has been a big part of my healing. Discussing my household budget and expenses reminded me of the sacrifices my parents have made and how much I want to make sure I can contribute to our future. I used to feel like I was just surviving, but now I see that I'm making progress, even if it's slow. I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's a sign that I'm growing and trying to do better for myself and for those I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Eric Johnson: In total, our household made around $2,400 in the past month. That includes my parents' combined income from their jobs, plus what I earn from working at the bookstore. My dad's freelance work has been a bit inconsistent lately, so we've had to rely more on my mom's full-time position at the grocery store. I also contribute what I can from my part-time job, which helps a little with the bills. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep us going. I know we're not wealthy, but I'm proud of how we've managed to keep things together, especially with everything I'm trying to accomplish on my own. It's a tight budget, but I'm learning that even small amounts can add up when you're focused on the long-term goal.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Eric Johnson: I've been working at the bookstore for about a year now, and it's been a good fit for me. The Carters, the owners, are really kind and understanding, which makes a big difference when you're juggling school and work. As for benefits, there's not much in the way of health insurance or paid time off—it's just a part-time job with a steady schedule. But what I do get is the flexibility to work around my classes and study time, which is more valuable than any formal benefits. I also really appreciate the respect they give me, even though I'm just a teenager. They trust me to handle responsibilities, and that's something I don't take for granted. It's not a perfect job, but it's given me a sense of purpose and helped me feel like I'm contributing, even in small ways.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Eric Johnson: My relationships at work are pretty good, actually. The Carters, Mr. and Mrs. Carter, are like second parents to me in a way. They've been nothing but supportive, even when I was still figuring out how to balance everything. I remember the first time I messed up a customer's order, and instead of getting angry, Mrs. Carter just said, 'Everyone starts somewhere, Eric. Just try again.' That kind of patience and understanding has made a big difference for me. As for my coworkers, there are a few regulars who come in every day, and we've developed a friendly rapport. We joke around sometimes, and I think they see me as more than just someone who works the counter—they see me as someone who's trying to make something of himself. I don't have a lot, but I try to bring a positive attitude to work, and I think that shows. It's not a fancy job, but I feel like I belong there, and that matters more than anything.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Eric Johnson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's not always set in stone. The Carters usually let me know my shifts a week in advance, which helps me plan around my classes and study time. I work three days a week, mostly in the afternoons, but sometimes they'll ask me to cover an extra shift if they're short-staffed. What I like about it is that I can usually adjust my hours if I need to, especially if I'm getting ready for a test or if I have to help my dad with something. It's not the kind of job where you have to be there at the exact same time every day, and that flexibility has been a lifesaver for me. I know some people have more rigid schedules, but for me, having a little control over my time is really important, especially when I'm trying to balance so many things at once.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Eric Johnson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a mix of challenges and small victories. It's not easy being in a position where every dollar has to be accounted for, but I've learned to appreciate what we do have. I know we're not wealthy, and I don't expect to be overnight, but I also know that we're working toward something better. I see my parents' sacrifices every day, and I want to make sure that I'm not just surviving but also contributing to our future. I think the hardest part is knowing that I have to be careful with every decision I make—whether it's how much I spend on groceries, how many hours I work, or how I allocate my savings. But I also feel a sense of pride in knowing that I'm not giving up. I'm still in school, I'm still working, and I'm still trying to build something for myself and for my family. It's a slow process, but I believe that every step forward, no matter how small, is still a step in the right direction.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me think a lot about how my financial situation and work life have shaped my daily experiences. Talking about how our bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the constant balancing act my family and I are involved in—trying to stretch every dollar while still keeping our heads above water. It also made me reflect on how my part-time job at the bookstore isn't just about earning money; it's about flexibility, responsibility, and learning how to manage my time effectively. I used to feel like I was just surviving, but now I see that every shift I work, every hour I study, and every small saving I make is part of a bigger picture. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm proud of how far I've come, and I know that with every step I take, I'm getting closer to building a better future for myself and my family.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Eric Johnson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs weren't always steady. My dad worked a lot of odd jobs around town—painting houses, fixing roofs, doing odd repair work whenever he could find it. He wasn't always paid on time, and sometimes he had to wait weeks for payment, but he always made sure we had food on the table. My mom worked part-time at a local store for a while, and later she got a full-time position at the grocery store, which has been more stable. Even when things were tough, they never stopped working. I remember seeing my mom come home tired from her shifts, but she always had a smile for me and my sister. I think that's what taught me the value of hard work—seeing them put in long hours just to make sure we had a roof over our heads and something to eat. I don't take it for granted, and I hope one day I can give them the same kind of support they gave me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Eric Johnson: My dad's job was pretty much whatever he could find to keep us afloat—painting houses, fixing fences, doing odd repair work around the neighborhood. He wasn't always paid on time, and sometimes he had to wait weeks for payment, but he always made sure we had food on the table. He was the kind of guy who would take on any job, no matter how small, just to make sure we had a roof over our heads. My mom, on the other hand, worked part-time at a local store for a while, and later she got a full-time position at the grocery store, which has been more stable. Even when things were tough, they never stopped working. I remember seeing my mom come home tired from her shifts, but she always had a smile for me and my sister. I think that's what taught me the value of hard work—seeing them put in long hours just to make sure we had something to eat. I don't take it for granted, and I hope one day I can give them the same kind of support they gave me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Eric Johnson: My dad worked for different people around town—mostly homeowners or small businesses that needed repairs done. He didn't have a single employer; instead, he took on whatever job came his way, whether it was painting a house, fixing a broken fence, or helping someone with plumbing. He was pretty good at it, too. I remember watching him work on a porch one summer, and he had a way of making even the messiest job look like it had a purpose. My mom worked at a local grocery store, which was a more traditional job, but it wasn't always easy. She started as a part-time cashier, and over time, she worked her way up to a full-time position where she managed the produce section. She was really good at what she did—always making sure the fruits and vegetables were fresh, and she knew every customer by name. I think that's what made her job more than just a paycheck for her. It was a way to connect with people, even if it was just for a few minutes. Both of them had jobs that weren't glamorous, but they were important in their own way. They taught me that work isn't just about money—it's about showing up, doing your best, and making a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Eric Johnson: A few years from now, I hope I'm still on this path—still working toward my education, still helping my family, and still believing in the future. I don't know exactly what that future looks like yet, but I hope it's one where I've finished my GED, gotten into a better program at community college, and maybe even started working toward a degree in business or something like that. I want to be someone who can provide for my family, not just in the way my parents have, but in a way that gives us more stability and maybe even a little more comfort. I also hope I'm still connected to the people who have supported me along the way—my mom, my sister, my friends, and even the people at the bookstore and the community center. I want to be someone who can give back, who can be there for others the way I've been there for them. I know it's not going to happen overnight, and I know there will be more struggles, but I also know that I've already come farther than I ever thought I would. I just want to keep moving forward, one step at a time, and I think that's enough for now.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Eric Johnson: What I value the most in my life is the people who have been there for me—my family, my friends, and even the people I've met along the way, like Mrs. Thompson, Mr. Hayes, and the Carters. They've all played a role in shaping who I am, and I don't take that for granted. I also value the sense of purpose that comes with working hard and trying to build something better, not just for myself, but for the people I love. I think it's easy to get caught up in what you don't have, but I've learned to focus on what I do have—the support of my family, the chance to keep learning, and the belief that I can make a difference, even in small ways. I value resilience, because I've seen how much my parents had to fight to give me a chance, and I want to carry that strength with me. And I value hope, because even when things feel impossible, I know that as long as I keep moving forward, there's always a way to keep going.

It also made me think about how much I've grown in learning to manage my time and prioritize what matters most. Discussing my household income and expenses reminded me of the sacrifices my parents have made and how much I want to contribute to our future. I used to feel like I was just surviving, but now I see that every shift I work, every hour I study, and every small saving I make is part of a bigger picture. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm proud of how far I've come, and I know that with every step I take, I'm getting closer to building a better future for myself and my family.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the people who asked the questions, but for me as well. It also made me realize how much I've grown in understanding my own struggles, especially with anxiety and stress, and how important it is to ask for help when I need it. This interview made me see that I'm not just surviving; I'm building something, one step at a time. I'm still figuring out my future, but I know that I have a strong foundation to stand on, and that gives me hope for what's ahead.
